column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Causalstatements|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Researchquestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|
#Text=Using demographic modeling to develop post_fire restoration strategies for a native shrub in a sage scrub community.

#Text=Diane M Thomson\rFirst published: 09 September 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14274\rAuthor contributions: DMT conceived of and conducted the demographic data collection and modeling research and wrote the manuscript.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Fernando Valladares\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\rSHARE.
#Text=Abstract.
#Text=Mediterranean_climate shrublands are key biodiversity hotspots and carbon storage pools, but are increasingly threatened by climate change, non_native species, and altered fire regimes.
#Text=Fires are important to historic shrubland disturbance cycles but can also promote non_native plants, which may limit post_fire native shrub recovery.
#Text=Increasing drought with climate change could also reduce post_fire shrub regeneration.

#Text=I developed a stochastic, individual_based demographic model (IBM) for the native shrub�Artemisia californica, parameterized from an experimental removal of non_native annuals after a 2013 fire in southern California.
#Text=The IBM simulated�A. californica�recovery for 7 years after fire under different rainfall conditions (drought or pre_drought) and non_native removal strategies (from no years to all 7 years).
#Text=Drought lowered�A. californica�canopy volume 7 years after fire by 90% or more.
#Text=Rainfall in the second year after fire, when most�A. californica�germination occurred, had particularly strong effects on final canopy cover.
#Text=Non_native removal in all 7 years increased canopy volume by three times under drought conditions and 3.5 times under pre_drought conditions.
#Text=Targeting non_native removal in the first 2 years proved nearly as effective, achieving from 88% (drought) to 95% (pre_drought) the benefits of removal in all 7 years.

#Text=In sum, low rainfall may be the most important limitation on post_fire shrub recovery, but removal of non_natives in years of pulsed shrub recruitment can be an effective restoration strategy even under drought conditions.
#Text=More generally, this study illustrates how demographic models can help optimize the targeting of scarce management and restoration resources.
#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Drought conditions similar to those experienced in California from 2011 to 2017 reduce post_fire�Artemisia californica�regeneration by as much as 90%.

#Text=Removing non_native annuals can ameliorate some of these impacts.\r* For shrubs that predominately regenerate from seeds after fire, recruitment is often pulsed in the first few years; targeting non_native removal to this period may be nearly as effective in promoting shrub recovery as non_native removal every year.\r* Low rainfall in years with post_fire pulses in seed germination substantially slows native shrub recovery.

#Text=Under drought conditions, additional years of non_native management may further benefit shrub regeneration.\r* Demographic models parameterized by linking plant survival and recruitment with environmental conditions can be a powerful approach for evaluating post_fire management and restoration options.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Mediterranean_climate shrublands represent key global biodiversity hotspots and carbon storage pools (Rundel et al�2016), but are also highly threatened by urban development, biological invasions, climate change, and altered fire regimes (Underwood et al�2009).
#Text=These factors often interact, potentially generating feedback effects.
#Text=For example, post_fire colonization by non_native, inflammable grass species may increase subsequent fire frequency and accelerate shrub loss (Park & Jenerette�2019).

#Text=Widespread degradation due to such anthropogenic impacts has generated strong interest in identifying effective restoration approaches for these habitats (Vallejo et al�2012; Mucina et al�2017).

#Text=Mathematical and simulation models can be powerful tools for evaluating potential management and restoration strategies, especially in systems responding to multiple, interacting factors such as fire and climate change (Schultz & Crone�1998; Hall et al�2021).

#Text=Several recent studies of Mediterranean_type shrublands use statistical models to identify environmental drivers of vegetation change (Shriver et al�2018) or climate suitability models to characterize potential habitat (Richardson & Chaney�2018; Schlaepfer et al�2021).
#Text=This research has yielded valuable insights, but translating such findings into specific recommendations feasible for local managers can be challenging (Kettenring & Adams�2011).
#Text=Demographic models are commonly used to evaluate different management and restoration options by predicting their consequences for population change.
#Text=Yet, such studies typically focus on rare or endemic taxa rather than more dominant species that may most strongly affect community structure (Bialic_Murphy et al�2017).
#Text=I drew on demographic data for the common southern California shrub�Artemisia californicato explore the use of population models in guiding post_fire restoration.
#Text=�Artemisia californicaoccurs in two shrub community types once widespread in southern California: sage scrub and chaparral.
#Text=Both habitats have been heavily impacted by development as well as type conversion, meaning replacement of shrubs by non_native grasses and forbs (Park & Jenerette�2019).
#Text=As much as 86% of historic sage scrub habitat has been destroyed, and by 1994, shrub cover in the remaining habitat had declined from 60 to 90% to only 36% (Minnich & Dezzani�1998).
#Text=Similarly, an estimated 19% of chaparral habitat has been lost over the last 75 years, and nearly a third more experienced declines in woody cover of greater than 25% (Syphard et al�2022).
#Text=Both chaparral and sage scrub evolved under regular fire, with historical (pre_European) return intervals estimated at 20_40 years (Keeley & Fotheringham�2001; Safford & Van de Water�2013).
#Text=Native shrubs in these communities are adapted for post_fire regeneration via resprouting, germination from the seed bank, or both (Keeley et al�2006).
#Text=Still, the spread of non_native plants has altered trajectories of post_fire recovery.
#Text=Fires create windows of opportunity for non_natives to establish, potentially increasing the probability of type conversion.
#Text=Rapid post_fire regeneration of shrub cover is critical, as established shrubs suppress nonnative grasses and forbs (Davies et al�2019).
#Text=Once type conversion occurs, reestablishing shrubs can be difficult and costly (Allen et al�2000; DeSimone�2011), or even infeasible (Cox & Allen�2008).
#Text=High cover of non_native grasses can suppress native shrub establishment through multiple mechanisms.
#Text=For species dependent on regeneration from seed, grass thatch may reduce germination (Molinari & D'Antonio�2020).
#Text=Competition with non_native grasses for shallow soil water resources also lowers the survival of some native shrub seedlings (Eliason & Allen�1997).

#Text=In addition, some studies suggest that type conversion changes foraging behavior of native herbivores (Halligan�1974) or alters the soil environment (Pickett et al�2019) in ways that favor non_native plants.
#Text=Given these challenges, one alternative is to prioritize early interventions that promote more rapid native shrub recovery after fire.

#Text=Such an approach recognizes that historical successional processes alone will not be sufficient to recover communities after disturbance because of environmental changes such as the spread of non_native species (Suding et al�2004).

#Text=Some studies support that removal of non_native grasses and forbs enhances native shrub establishment, both after fire and in the absence of disturbance (Schultz�1996; Eliason & Allen�1997; Cione et al�2002).
#Text=Strategic temporal targeting of removal efforts may be critical, given that post_fire recruitment for many species in these communities is highly pulsed.
#Text=For example, a 5_year post_fire study of southern California chaparral and sage scrub found that most seedlings emerged within the first 2 years (Keeley et al�2006).

#Text=Moreover, short_term removal of non_natives to facilitate native regeneration may be more cost_effective and achieve greater success than efforts to completely eradicate or suppress non_natives over a longer time period (Simberloff�2009; Kettenring & Adams�2011).

#Text=Increasingly severe drought conditions due to climate change create another barrier to post_fire shrub regeneration, with potential implications for the effectiveness of non_native control efforts.

#Text=Moisture availability has been identified as one of the most important constraints on post_fire shrub recovery, in sage scrub (Kimball et al�2014), chaparral (Storey et al�2021), and other western North American shrublands (Werner et al�2022).
#Text=Over the past decade, California has experienced some of the most severe heat and water stress documented for the last 1200 years (Griffin & Anchukaitis�2014; Dong et al�2019).
#Text=These conditions may increase the likelihood of type conversion and could undermine the benefits of non_native removal (Jacobsen & Pratt�2018; Puritty et al�2019).

#Text=While a number of researchers have raised concerns about drought effects on southern California shrublands, studies that assess interactions between the effects of non_natives and water stress are unusual.

#Text=Post_fire studies often rely on chronosequences or space for time substitutions, constraining the range of environmental conditions that can be explored (Meng et al�2014; Shriver et al�2018; Syphard et al�2022).

#Text=I developed a stochastic, individual_based demographic model (IBM) for�A. californicarecovery over the first 7 years after fire, using data from a non_native removal experiment conducted following a 2013 fire in sage scrub (Thomson et al�2021).
#Text=I used statistical models to parameterize the IBM by linking�A. california�recruitment, survival, and growth with both non_native removal treatments and annual rainfall.
#Text=The IBM then projected�A. californicarecovery under a range of rainfall and non_native removal scenarios.

#Text=Models were used to address the hypothesis that management of non_native plants in the first years after fire can promote�A. californica�regeneration, and specifically the following questions:\r1.
#Text=How do drought, non_native plants, and their interactions affect post_fire regeneration of�A. californica \r2.
#Text=How much does non_native removal in the first seven post_fire years enhance�A. californica�regeneration \r3.
#Text=Can the removal of non_natives in a subset of years achieve benefits comparable to those of removing non_natives in all 7 years \r4.
#Text=Do drought conditions affect the benefits of non_native removal or change the relative effectiveness of targeting removal in particular years \rMethods.
#Text=Study Site.
#Text=Data were collected at the Robert J.

#Text=Bernard Field Station, a suburban site containing fragments of intact sage scrub in a matrix of disturbed habitats such as non_native grasslands (Fig�S1; 34.8 ha; 34 degrees 6 N, 117 degrees 42 W; 348 m elevation; Claremont, CA, U.S.A.).
#Text=The local climate is Mediterranean, with cool, wet winters followed by a lengthy, warm, summer_to_fall drought period.
#Text=Winter rains typically start in October and end in April or May.

#Text=Growing year rainfall (September to August) averages 415.5 mm (n = 95 years with complete records; 1896_1979 National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Claremont Station; 2000_2020 Western Regional Climate Center data for Claremont, CA, U.S.A.).
#Text=Over the study period, growing year rainfall varied from 55.4% below to 79.3% above this mean (Table�S1).
#Text=In September 2013, an accidental fire burned 6.9 ha containing approximately 5000 m2�of sage scrub in two main patches, each bordered by non_native grassland.

#Text=Rainfall in the first post_fire growing year almost exactly equaled the 2000_2020 mean, the second and third years were each approximately 25% below average, and the fourth year was 44% above average (Table�S1).

#Text=Artemisia californica�dominated pre_fire cover in both burned patches (mean +/- one standard error of the mean [SEM] 2012_2013 foliar cover, west patch: 47.4 +/- 4.8%, east patch: 30.1 +/- 3.7%).

#Text=Previous studies have identified�A. californica�as a facultative seeder capable of resprouting after fire, but at lower rates (13_25%) than observed for other shrubs in this ecosystem (Thomson et al�2021).

#Text=Data Collection and Experiment\rI estimated the effects of non_native removal and rainfall on�A. californica�demographic rates (survival, growth, and seedling emergence) using data from the first seven growing years after the 2013 fire.
#Text=Twelve 10 m   10 m plots separated by 5 m buffers and spanning the area of burned scrub were established.
#Text=Within neighboring pairs of plots, one was randomly assigned to control and the other to non_native removal treatments.

#Text=Non_native grasses and forbs were hand weeded from removal plots for the first 4 years after fire (spring 2014_2017) by two to three volunteers working for 20 minutes once per week from mid_January until the end of March.
#Text=The most common non_native species removed included the annual grasses�Bromus diandrus�and�B. madritensis, and the annual forbs�Erodium�spp,�Brassica nigra, and�Hirschfeldia incana.
#Text=All�A. californica�in the study plots were mapped, tagged, and monitored for survival and growth from 2014 to 2021 at an annual census in mid_June.
#Text=I measured size as canopy volume, calculated from plant height and diameters of the longest axis and perpendicular to the longest axis.
#Text=Seedlings likewise were individually mapped, measured, and monitored, except in two springs when high emergence rates precluded tagging all seedlings (2015 and 2019).

#Text=In 2015, I used subsampling on a grid within each plot to estimate seedling abundance and survival, while in 2019, all seedlings were counted and a subset tagged for monitoring survival and growth.
#Text=Additional details can be found in Thomson et al (2021).
#Text=Model Parameterization\rAll statistical analyses were implemented in R (version 3.6.1).

#Text=I quantified effects of non_native removal and rainfall on�A. californica�demographic rates in the R package lme4, with binomial generalized linear mixed effects models for survival and linear mixed effects models for growth and seedling abundance (Bates et al�2015).

#Text=Total precipitation from January through June was used as the rainfall predictor because these are the months when�A. californica�is most actively growing (National Climate Data Center records, Claremont, CA, U.S.A.).
#Text=From 2000 to 2020, spring precipitation strongly correlated with total growing year precipitation (r = 0.94).
#Text=Spring precipitation values were normalized as a proportional deviation from the mean for 2000_2020.
#Text=I log_transformed plant sizes before analysis.
#Text=I classified all records from 2018 to 2020 as from control conditions, given non_native removal treatments ended after 2017.

#Text=Although cover data are not available from 2018 to 2020, by 2021 control and removal plots did not differ for either non_native forbs (t = 0.27, degrees of freedom [df] = 10,�p = 0.79) or non_native grasses (t = 1.33,�df = 10,�p = 0.21).
#Text=Past studies at this site using hand removal methods found that non_native annuals rapidly reestablish once treatment stops (Thomson et al�2016).

#Text=Further, limiting the analysis to years when the experimental removals were carried out (2014_2017) did not change any of the qualitative patterns and would have substantially reduced sample sizes.
#Text=Survival models for established plants used tag number (individual plant identity) as a random effect.
#Text=Previous analyses found that only smaller plants benefitted from non_native removal (Thomson et al�2021).
#Text=To better capture this effect, I divided established plants into two categories: small (</=0.007 m3�canopy volume) and large (>0.007 m3�canopy volume).
#Text=The final small plant model included positive effects of size, rainfall, and non_native removal on survival (Table�S2).
#Text=The final large plant model included positive effects of size and rainfall and no effects of non_native removal (Table�S2).
#Text=The seedling survival analysis used plot as a random effect to account for repeated measures.
#Text=The final seedling survival model included positive effects of higher rainfall and non_native removal, as well as a positive interaction between them (Table�S2).

#Text=Separate growth models were developed for three size categories (seedlings/small, medium, and large) because of non_linearity in the effects of previous size and greater variance in growth for smaller sizes (Table�S2).

#Text=Sizes of seedlings and the smallest established plants (canopy volume <0.00034 m3) in the second year of a June_to_June transition showed no relationships with non_native removal, rainfall, or size in the previous year.
#Text=However, seedlings that germinated in the first two post_fire years (2013_2014 and 2014_2015) grew bigger than those from 2016 to 2019.

#Text=The growth model for medium plants (0.00034_0.78 m3�canopy volume) included previous size and positive effects of rainfall; for large plants (>0.78 m3), size in the second year of a transition depended only on previous size.
#Text=Seedling abundances showed no significant relationships with either non_native removal or rainfall.
#Text=I calculated the total number of seedlings present at the June census each year, either as the total of direct counts or estimated using densities measured with subsampling (in 2015).
#Text=Seedling emergence concentrated heavily into the first (9% of total) and particularly the second (82.9% of total) year after fire (Table�S3).
#Text=Very few seedlings emerged after 2015, except in the wetter spring of 2019 (5.6%).
#Text=Individual_Based Model\rI developed a stochastic IBM in R to simulate effects of rainfall and non_native removal strategies on�A. californica�recovery after fire.

#Text=An IBM more readily accommodates demographic stochasticity and non_equilibrium conditions typical after a major disturbance, compared to more aggregated approaches like matrix models (Ak�akaya & Brook�2009).
#Text=Each simulation began with seven individuals that survived the September 2013 fire as resprouts.
#Text=The IBM then predicted individual survival and growth, as well as addition of new plants from seedling recruitment, for seven annual transitions.
#Text=This time scale aligns with study goals to understand limitations on initial post_fire recovery.
#Text=Also, data from 2014 to 2021 were available to assess how well the IBM predicted observed changes after fire.

#Text=I compared seven management strategies implementing non_native plant removal in different years: no removal (control), and then removal in year 1 only, year 2 only, years 1_2, years 2_3, years 1_4, or years 1_7.
#Text=Effects of these management strategies were assessed under two different rainfall scenarios, pre_drought and drought.

#Text=I defined pre_drought conditions as starting with the first complete precipitation records for the study site in 1999_2000 and continuing until the onset of severe drought in fall of 2011 (mean spring rainfall +/- SEM = 412.2 +/- 74.3 mm,�n = 12; Table�S1).

#Text=Growing years from 2011_2012 through 2019_2020 were used to characterize drought conditions, although this period included two above_average rain years (mean spring rainfall +/- SEM = 257.3 +/- 57.2 mm,�n = 9).
#Text=Simulations.
#Text=I ran 2000 replicate stochastic simulations for each of the seven treatment scenarios, under both pre_drought and drought rainfall conditions.
#Text=For each simulation year, a random spring rainfall value was drawn from those observed during the appropriate time period (pre_drought, spring 2000_2011; drought, spring 2012_2020; Table�S1).
#Text=All management scenarios were simulated under the same 2000 randomly drawn series of rain years, within a given rainfall condition (pre_drought or drought).

#Text=The IBM determined the survival probability for each plant already present in the population, using the appropriate fixed effects survival model (see Section�2.3) and adding individual variation by drawing from a random normal distribution with mean 0 and the standard deviation from the random effects estimate.
#Text=Binomial draws with the resulting probabilities then assigned each plant as either surviving or dying.

#Text=The IBM added new recruits by drawing out a total number of seedlings for the year, calculating the probability of seedling survival with the estimated survival model, then carrying out a binomial draw with the resulting probability to determine the number of surviving seedlings.
#Text=Simulations always used the exact number of seedlings observed in the study plots for years one and two, when most post_fire seedling emergence was concentrated.
#Text=In subsequent simulated years, the model randomly sampled a seedling number from the remaining 5 years of data (2016_2020).

#Text=The IBM calculated growth for seedlings and small plants by randomly drawing a new value for surviving individuals, from all the sizes observed in the second year of a transition for their size category.
#Text=Second year sizes for seedlings that emerged in the first 2 years after fire were drawn from values for the larger 2013_2014 and 2014_2015 recruits.
#Text=For medium and large plants, their respective growth models were used to generate sizes in the following year.
#Text=Assessing Model Uncertainty.
#Text=I evaluated how two alternative assumptions about plant survival affected model predictions.
#Text=First, previous analyses found that non_native removal benefited smaller plants (Thomson et al�2021).
#Text=However, this effect was no longer statistically significant when I modeled small and large plant survival separately.
#Text=The baseline IBM included this nonsignificant treatment effect, but I repeated the simulations using an alternative survival model with no removal effect on small plants.
#Text=Second, I explored potential density_dependence in plant survival.
#Text=Only for large plants, there was a nonsignificant potential trend for lower survival in plots with more plants (p = 0.15).
#Text=I carried out additional simulations that included this density_dependent reduction in survival for large plants.
#Text=Finally, I ran simulations using the exact time series of spring rainfall values at the study site from 2014 to 2020, for comparison with observed plant numbers and canopy volume in 2021.

#Text=Both control (no removal) and removal in years 1_4 strategies were simulated under actual rainfall conditions, and the results averaged, since half of the study site received non_native removal treatments in the first 4 years after fire.
#Text=Analysis of Simulation Results\rFinal population size tightly correlated with total canopy volume (r = 0.87).
#Text=I used log_transformed total canopy volume after 7 years as the single response measure, and all resulting statistical models met assumptions of linearity, normality, and equality of variances.

#Text=I first tested the effects of rainfall conditions (pre_drought vs. drought), the amount of spring rainfall specifically in year 2, and management strategy on log_transformed final canopy volume, with the R function lm().
#Text=The effects of rainfall were clearly non_linear, and I evaluated both quadratic and cubic polynomial terms.
#Text=I also included interactions between management strategy and rainfall conditions, as well as between management strategy and all three terms for rainfall in year 2.
#Text=There was no evidence of an interaction between management strategy and the cubic term for rainfall in year 2 (F[6,2795] = 0.96,�p = 0.44); this interaction was not included in the final model.
#Text=Given strong interactions of rainfall conditions with management strategy, I used separate analyses to assess differences between the seven management strategies.

#Text=Two separate one_way Analyses of Variance (ANOVAs) were conducted (one for pre_drought and one for drought conditions), each followed by Tukey's post hocs in the R package multcomp (version 1.4.0) for pairwise comparisons (Hothorn et al�2008).
#Text=Results.

#Text=Rainfall conditions (pre_drought vs. drought) explained more of the variation in total�Artemisia californica�canopy volume 7 years after fire than any other predictor (F[1,27,971] = 66,386,�p < 0.0001; Table�S4; Fig�1).
#Text=Even with no removal treatment, pre_drought conditions produced more than 10 times the mean canopy volume predicted under drought (Table�1).
#Text=Higher rainfall specifically in the second growing year after fire also strongly increased canopy volume (F[1,27,971] = 13,129,�p < 0.0001; Fig�1).
#Text=Canopy volume differed significantly across management (non_native removal) strategies (F[6,27,971] = 1410,�p < 0.0001; Table�1).
#Text=Non_native removal also interacted with second year rainfall (F[6,27,971] = 5.2,�p < 0.0001).

#Text=Management strategies involving non_native removal in the second year after fire enhanced the benefits of higher second year rainfall, although these positive effects saturated at higher rainfall (Table�S5; Fig�1).

#Text=Figure 1\r\rEffects of rainfall scenario (pre_drought = green, drought = yellow) and spring rainfall specifically in the second post_fire year on predicted natural log_transformed total canopy volume 7 years after fire.

#Text=Panels show results for different non_native removal strategies, ranging from no removal (bottom right) to removal in only year 1, only year 2, years 2_3, 1_2, 1_4, or 1_7 (top left) after fire.
#Text=Each point represents a single simulation, and lines show a third_order polynomial fit, consistent with the statistical model used (Table�S4).
#Text=Table 1.

#Text=�Back_transformed means and 95% lower (LB) and upper (UB) bounds of simulated�A. californica�total canopy volume at 7 years post_fire, under different rainfall (pre_drought or drought) and non_native removal strategies.
#Text=The last column scales canopy volumes as a proportion of the maximum observed under the same rainfall conditions.

#Text=Rainfall conditions\rNon_native removal strategy\rMean canopy volume (m3)\r95% LB (m3)\r95% UB (m3)\rProportion of maximum\rDrought\rNone\r66.95\r65.52\r68.41\r0.33\r\rY1\r84.18\r82.33\r86.07\r0.42\r\rY2\r156.43\r152.54\r160.43\r0.78\r\rY1_2\r176.36\r172.03\r180.81\r0.88\r\rY2_3\r178.13\r173.82\r182.54\r0.89\r\rY1_4\r200.18\r195.41\r205.06\r1.00\r\rY1_7\r200.34\r195.56\r205.24\r1.00\rPre_drought\rNone\r685.05\r670.71\r699.69\r0.29\r\rY1\r940.74\r921.74\r960.13\r0.40\r\rY2\r1975.87\r1930.31\r2022.50\r0.83\r\rY1_2\r2262.29\r2212.37\r2313.33\r0.95\r\rY2_3\r2075.28\r2028.54\r2123.11\r0.87\r\rY1_4\r2364.78\r2313.34\r2417.35\r0.99\r\rY1_7\r2377.08\r2325.73\r2429.56\r1.00\rAll management strategies that included non_native removal in the second year after fire led to a higher total canopy volume than either no removal or removal only in year 1 (Table�S6; Fig�2).
#Text=The effects of non_native removal in years 2_3 did not differ from those of removal in years 1_2, for either pre_drought or drought conditions.
#Text=Applying non_native removal for more than 2 years further increased total canopy volume only with drought rainfall (Table�S6; Fig�2).

#Text=Under drought conditions, strategies with more years of non_native removal always generated higher canopy volume than those with fewer, except that removal in all 7 years did not differ from removal in years 1_4.
#Text=In contrast, under pre_drought conditions, non_native removal in years 1_2 achieved the same total canopy volume as removal in years 1_4 or 1_7.

#Text=Figure 2\r\rBoxplot comparing the effects of different non_native removal strategies under pre_drought (green) and drought (yellow) conditions, on natural log_transformed canopy volumes predicted at 7 years after fire.
#Text=Different letters indicate statistically significant differences between removal treatments, as determined by Tukey's honestly significant difference post hoc tests.
#Text=All pre_drought scenarios led to significantly greater canopy volume than any drought scenarios.
#Text=Removing non_natives either in all years (1_7) or in years 1_4 led to the highest values for total canopy volumes under both pre_drought and drought rainfall (Table�1).
#Text=With no non_native removal in any year, total canopy volume fell to 28.8% (pre_drought) and 33.4% (drought) of those maxima.
#Text=Removing non_natives only in year 2 increased total canopy volume to 83.1% (pre_drought) and 78.1% (drought) of the maxima.
#Text=Treating in years 1_2 increased the benefit of non_native removal to 95.1% (pre_drought) and 88.0% (drought) of the maxima.
#Text=Changes made in model assumptions to assess uncertainty did affect some results.
#Text=Assuming that only seedling and not small plant survival increased with non_native removal reduced the magnitude of treatment effects, particularly under drought conditions (Table�S7).
#Text=This change also increased the importance of non_native removal in years with higher seedling emergence (the first and second post_fire).
#Text=For pre_drought rainfall, models without treatment effects on small plants led to higher canopy volume for non_native removal in years 1_2 than for removal in years 2_3.
#Text=Under drought conditions, additional gains in canopy volume from removing non_natives in years 1_4 or 1_7 disappeared; these strategies did not differ from removal in years 1_2 (Table�S7).
#Text=Including density_dependence in large adult survival reduced the predicted total canopy volume, more so for treatment strategies involving more years of non_native removal (Table�S8).
#Text=Nevertheless, pairwise comparisons between treatment strategies yielded the same results regardless of assumptions about density_dependence.
#Text=In June 2021, a total of 118 adult plants were present in the 1200 m2�study area, 19 in control plots and 99 in plots treated with non_native removal.
#Text=Canopy volume totaled 123.2 m3�(23.5 m3�control plots, 99.7 m3�removal plots).
#Text=IBM simulations with rainfall and non_native removal identical to the study conditions predicted mean plant numbers of 102.7 and mean total canopy volume of 157.1 m3.
#Text=The IBM underpredicted�A. californica�abundance, with the number of plants observed in 2021 falling into the highest 2.9% of simulation results.
#Text=At the same time, the IBM overpredicted total canopy volume, with the observed 2021 value falling in the lowest 4.7% of simulation results.
#Text=This difference between observed and predicted log canopy volume (0.24 log m3) was small relative to the effects of rainfall conditions and non_native removal (Figs.�1�&�2).
#Text=Discussion.

#Text=This study illustrates how a demographic model linking plant vital rates with rainfall and a non_native removal experiment can be used to compare the consequences of management options for population growth.

#Text=Although drought emerged as by far the most important constraint on�Artemisia californica�recovery, removing non_native plants for the first 7 years after fire still generated approximately threefold increases in predicted�A. californica�cover.
#Text=Targeted non_native removal in just the first 2 years after fire proved 88% (drought rainfall) or 95% (pre_drought rainfall) as effective as removal in all years.
#Text=Interestingly, removing non_natives in additional years led to modest increased benefits, but more so for drought than pre_drought rainfall conditions.
#Text=The results of this IBM reinforce other work showing precipitation and soil moisture are key drivers of post_fire shrub recovery.
#Text=Similar to my findings, restoration plantings in sage scrub during two drought years led to much lower total native cover relative to one wetter year (DeSimone�2011).
#Text=A post_fire experiment found that reducing water availability lowered native cover and growth of�A. californica�resprouts while increasing non_native grasses (Kimball et al�2014).
#Text=Those findings suggest non_native grasses may be able to exploit drought conditions, increasing the risk of type conversion when dry years follow fire.

#Text=Recent analyses of remote sensing data in southern California chaparral identified lower site moisture availability as the strongest predictor of type replacement by herbaceous vegetation (Park et al�2018; Park & Jenerette�2019).
#Text=Yet, none of these previous studies evaluated interactions between drought, time since fire, and non_native plants.
#Text=Kimball et al (2014) observed but did not manipulate higher grass densities in post_fire water reduction treatments.

#Text=Other research has assessed the benefits of non_native removal for seeded or planted native shrubs but at sites that had been type converted for some time, either unburned (Eliason & Allen�1997; Kimball et al�2019) or burned more than a decade before (Phillips & Allen�2023).

#Text=Many studies observe different outcomes in wet or dry years, but without quantifying relationships between rainfall and plant establishment, survival, or growth (Eliason & Allen�1997; Kimball et al�2019).
#Text=Some work on type conversion considers effects of moisture availability, but excluding recently burned areas (Shriver et al�2018; Park & Jenerette�2019).
#Text=My results illustrate the importance of including all three factors in the same analysis.
#Text=This approach was facilitated by simulating a wide range of environmental conditions, beyond those observed in the years of experimental manipulations.
#Text=My findings particularly reinforce that low precipitation in one of the first several years after fire could greatly reduce shrub recovery.
#Text=Higher spring rainfall in the second year after fire strongly increased�A. californica�cover.
#Text=Even under pre_drought conditions, 25% of years experienced rainfall below long_term averages; simulations that drew lower values in year two showed persistent reductions in�A. californica.

#Text=Urza et al (2021) likewise found for Great Basin�A. tridentata�that a single, favorable recruitment year driven by high soil moisture was associated with greater long_term cover than multiple, smaller recruitment events.
#Text=A similar pattern may explain why non_native removal beyond the first 2 years only enhanced�A. californica�cover under drought conditions.
#Text=The strong effect of rainfall timing reflects highly pulsed post_fire germination, with 83% of estimated seedling numbers over the first 7 years emerging in year 2.
#Text=Pulsed recruitment after disturbance is common in sage scrub and chaparral shrubs, although in some cases peaks during the first rather than second year.

#Text=Some researchers have hypothesized that resprouting shrubs contribute high seed rain in the first post_fire year, generating a surge in germination during year two (Malanson & O'Leary�1982; Keeley & Keeley�1984).
#Text=This explanation seems unlikely in my study, given that only seven�A. californica�resprouted.

#Text=Still, a number of studies document pulsed recruitment within the first one to 4 years after fire, for�A. californica, other shrubs in sage scrub and chaparral, and the related�A. tridentata(Keeley et al�2006; Ziegenhagen & Miller�2009).
#Text=These patterns of pulsed recruitment after fire facilitate targeting of management interventions but may also increase vulnerability to drought.

#Text=Since 2016, California has experienced several abrupt shifts from very dry to very wet conditions, and climate models predict that variability will continue to increase (Swain et al�2018); the potential for post_fire pulsed recruitment to occur in dry years may increase as well.
#Text=Germination cuing by seeds to exploit favorable rainfall conditions could ameliorate some drought effects.
#Text=My model assumed seedling emergence was independent of spring rainfall, but it is possible that peak emergence lagged to year 2 because of low precipitation during the first fall after fire.

#Text=Although seedling emergence rates were overall low in years 3_5 and 7 (4_47 individuals), another small peak of germination occurred in year 6 (181 individuals) when spring rainfall was 1.1 times the long_term historical average.

#Text=Rain early in the growing year likely to stimulate germination (November through January) broadly predicts later precipitation linked with survival (January through June) (r = 0.75), although with notable exceptions in years such as 2013_2014 (Thomson et al�2021).
#Text=Enhanced recruitment due to germination cuing may help explain why simulations using actual rainfall values underpredicted�A. californica�abundance in 2021.
#Text=Longer_term data would be valuable in better quantifying the link between rainfall and germination.
#Text=Nevertheless, chaparral and sage scrub shrub seeds are likely constrained in how long they can delay germination after fire, given recolonization by other vegetation.
#Text=For example, seeding�A. tridentata�Nutt. ssp.
#Text=�vaseyana�more than 4 years after fire did not promote recovery, potentially because of growth in herbaceous vegetation (Davies et al�2017).
#Text=The demographic rates influenced by non_native removal also shaped model outcomes.
#Text=Non_natives primarily reduced�A. californica�seedling survival, making removal treatments applied in the years of peak germination highly effective.
#Text=This result raises the question of whether other sites or shrub species would respond to non_native removal in similar ways.

#Text=A post_fire restoration study in sage scrub found higher�A. californica�seedling growth but no change in survival with non_native removal; however, these individuals were transplanted plugs with high survival rates (40_60%) (Kimball et al�2019).

#Text=In another restoration experiment with�A. californica, both germination rates and survival only for the first growing season increased with reductions in non_native grass density (Eliason & Allen�1997).

#Text=Non_native annual grasses substantially reduce soil water availability near the soil surface, changes likely to strongly affect seedlings but not larger and deeper_rooted individuals (Park & Jenerette�2019; Kainrath et al�2021).
#Text=This body of work suggests that other sites and shrub species will also respond to post_fire non_native removal primarily in early life stages.
#Text=Other important questions remain before the predictions of this model could be generalized into restoration applications elsewhere.
#Text=Volunteer_based hand control of non_natives proved effective at the study site, but on only 600 m2�of habitat.
#Text=Such labor_intensive approaches could be difficult to scale up, although a review of effective non_native control efforts cites multiple examples using hand removal (Simberloff�2009).

#Text=Citizen science participation is increasingly common in restoration and management; volunteers more typically help search for non_natives but could also contribute to non_native removal (de S� Dechoum et al�2019).
#Text=Comparing the effects of different non_native plant removal methods could clarify whether the benefits of hand removal can be replicated with more tractable approaches.
#Text=It is also important to better quantify potential legacy effects persisting after the year of treatment.
#Text=In this study, I assumed that non_native removal only affected�A. californica�in the years applied, potentially underestimating the benefits.
#Text=Fire history is another important factor that could come into play.
#Text=Recent work in chaparral supports that decreased fire return intervals play a major role in type conversion (Syphard et al�2022).
#Text=Repeated, short_interval fires can increase stress on established plants, reducing resprouting rates (Haidinger & Keeley�1993).
#Text=More frequent fires can also leave inadequate time for the soil seed bank to replenish (Keeley & Brennan�2012).
#Text=My study site had not burned in at least 50 years at the time of the 2013 fire.
#Text=In cases where the local seed bank is depleted, removing non_native plants might prove ineffective unless accompanied by seeding or planting (Davies et al�2019).

#Text=Other factors likely influence post_fire shrub recovery and would be valuable foci for future research, including soil characteristics, microclimate, and the identity and density of non_native species.
#Text=The modeling approach I used is also an important source of limitations in extrapolating the results and methods.

#Text=Stochastic IBMs are computationally intensive, and evaluating the effects of parameter uncertainty requires simulations, in contrast to the analytical analyses possible with matrix or integral projection models (Ak�akaya & Brook�2009).
#Text=This approach worked well to make short_term predictions for a small number of plants but would be more challenging for larger populations or longer time scales.
#Text=My model also assumed that seedling recruitment did not depend on the number of established�A. californica.
#Text=This assumption is reasonable in context, given that almost all established plants died in the fire and so recruits in the first few post_fire years likely emerged from the seed bank.
#Text=Still, predicting longer_term population change would require estimates of reproduction and seed rain.
#Text=These points reinforce that it is critical to select a model structure appropriate to the available data and research question.
#Text=In summary, these findings support post_fire restoration strategies for�A. californica�that prioritize non_native control in the first two growing years.
#Text=If establishment of new shrub recruits is low in the first two post_fire years due to adverse environmental conditions, continuing non_native removal in additional years may also be beneficial.

#Text=In general, non_native removal timed to correspond as closely as possible with pulsed seedling emergence after disturbance is more likely to benefit the recovery of shrubs with seed_dependent regeneration and persistent soil seed banks.

#Text=Increasing drought conditions due to climate change will likely reduce the capacity of�A. californica�to recover after fire, but the relative benefits of active restoration through non_native removal should remain high.
